column1: rynezion 160120934458 "2017-04-29 16:03:11 GMT" http://rynezion.tumblr.com/post/160120934458/magic-and-rules "daringthepen:  It may be extremely easy to just put magic into a story youâ€™re creating
column2: or explain away things with the excuse of â€œmagic.â€Â  But if that is how magic is handled in your world
column3: readers are going to find major plot holes in your story.Â  Magic needs rules and guidelines
column4: even in stories where itâ€™s not in the foreground.Â  Without rules
column5: magic could be the solution to all
column6: or you end overpowering a character because he has no restrictions on how he can use his magic. But where do you start when setting ground rules for how and when magic can be used?Â  My goal in this post is to give you some ideas while you map out your world of magic. Who can learn magic? Is magic a thing that all people can learn
column7: or certain people who have a knack for it?Â  Is magic something that can be learned at all?Â  Perhaps itâ€™s only readily available for those who are born with it
column8: such as the wizards in Harry Potter.Â  Or magic is contained in things
column11: or unicorn horns.Â  People may have to learn how to access the magic contained in these items
column12: but they are solely reliant on items in order to use magic.Â  Perhaps magic can only be learned by certain races. How is magic learned?Â  In Harry Potter
column13: wizards go to school for seven years to learn how to use magic.Â  Other books wizards have apprentices they train.Â Â Â  Can magic be self-taught?Â  How does a person access magic?Â  Through emotion
column15: something else?Â  Perhaps learning magic requires a large sacrifice. Does the magic need to be channeled?Â  Once again
column16: using the example of Harry Potter
column17: wizards need wands in order to use magic.Â  Other common themes involve wizards using staffs in order to use magic.Â  But there are stories where wizards donâ€™t need an item to channel the magic
column18: such as the wizards in the anime/manga series Fairy Tail.Â  Perhaps magic does need an item to be channeled through
column19: but it doesnâ€™t have to be the traditional wand or staff. How often can a person use magic? Does magic use up a personâ€™s energy
column20: and therefore a personâ€™s magic is limited to how much energy they have?Â  Perhaps they have a different â€œenergyâ€
column22: that restricts how much magic they can use?Â  Maybe you want to go the Once Upon a Time route and magic isnâ€™t used in excess because it comes with a price.Â  Perhaps how magic is used is why people donâ€™t use it so often.Â  Maybe magic is used very often. Does magic need incantations?Â  Harry Potter uses incantations
column23: whether is it is verbal or non-verbal.Â  There does not seem to be an incantations in the magic that the Witch uses in the Chronicles of Narnia.Â  Incantations are used quite often in the Septimus Heap series.Â  And there no incantations in Lord of the Rings.Â  Or maybe incantations are reserved for the more powerful
column24: older spells.Â  Perhaps incantations make a spell more stable.Â   Can magic be invoked by using items?Â  Potions is one of the common ways this is used.Â  But sometimes certain spells can only be invoked by using ingredients
column25: like in the show Charmed or the movie Practical Magic.Â  Perhaps itâ€™s only used occasionally
column26: such as some spells performed in the show Sabrina the Teenage Witch.Â  Maybe items are used in only certain branches
column27: such as Divination in Harry Potter. What cannot be done by magic?Â  With the Genieâ€™s magic in Disneyâ€™s Aladdin
column28: he could not make someone come back from the dead
column30: or grant more wishes.Â  Food cannot be created out of thin air according to the rules of magic in Harry Potter.Â  Actual love in Harry Potter canâ€™t be created
column31: but enchantments that cause the victim to have an obsessive type of love does exist.Â  Perhaps the dead can be raised
column32: as evidenced by stories with necromancy
column33: but it canâ€™t actually bring back the person completely.Â  Somethingâ€™s missing.Â  Perhaps only skeletons can be brought back
column34: or the person comes back in a zombie like state.Â  Perhaps you would go so far as to say that magic cannot create permanent things out of nothing. Does magic have categories/a way it is organized? Potions
column48: etc.Â  And it doesnâ€™t have to have only one way of organization.Â  It can have several levels
column49: just like when science organizes living organisms.Â    So these are few things to consider when creating magic.Â  The nature of your magic may not necessarily fit into all of these questions
column50: and thatâ€™s fine.Â  But donâ€™t be afraid to have long explanations for your magic.Â  You probably wonâ€™t fit it all in your story - in fact
column51: youâ€™ll want to be careful how you incorporate magic rules as you donâ€™t want to infodump on your readers - but having the rules there will help you create your story and give you some answers to the why questions that might come up
column53: â€œwhy donâ€™t they just magic themselves out?â€ " False text

column1: rynezion 160116060243 "2017-04-29 12:29:26 GMT" http://rynezion.tumblr.com/post/160116060243/writing-body-language "immortallionheart:  How to Improve your writing This is something that happens every day in your life. A shift of your eyebrow in skepticism
column2: or the way your lip may twitch to a half smile cause youâ€™re trying not to laugh. These behaviors are vital for writing in character
column3: because not only do the allow you to visually see what is happening but it is also reaffirming whatever emotion your character is showing. So why should you write it?  Much of human communication is non-verbal which means you need to also translate this non-verbal reaction in a post. It allows you to greatly enhance the emotions of another character and always another person to â€˜visuallyâ€™ see how they feel in a post. Most of all
column4: this will add depth and volume to your post to make it feel more real. IT will make your character feel like a human instead of just another fictional person you look at from above. Below you will find a list different type of emotions and what sort of body language can be exhibited to them.  Three ways to accent an action. When writing about emotions
column5: there are different ways to verbally write them out. Each one is unique in their own way
column6: allowing you to show more about the emotion. Emphasize the Emotion.But doing this
column7: you are expressing both the emotion and the body language. Weâ€™ll use a simple example. Itâ€™s short and simple yet you can sense he is happy.John felt so happy that he was humming a tune while walking down the hall. Complicate the Emotion.Sometimes
column8: even when you are feeling one emotion
column9: deep down rooted underneath the facade of it all
column10: there is actually an underlining emotion they feel. This is something you have to truly express otherwise no one will know.John felt so happy that he was humming a tune while walking down the hall. However
column11: it was obvious by the way his nose crinkled that he was disgusted by the actions beforehand. Instead
column12: John covered it up by appearing pleased today. Contradict the Emotion.This is a little different than complicate. Contradicting means that you are claiming oneÂ thing when in fact its the other. In many ways
column13: this has a variety of uses
column14: from inner depth of the truth to what you see in person
column15: or someone creating a wall. It could be considered a lie
column16: but when is anything that easy?John felt so happy that he was humming a tune while walking down the hall. In truth
column17: once he was in the classroom
column18: his shoulders slumped and a pout crossed his lips when no one was around
column19: showing just how displeased he was with the situation.  Remember that you do not always have to contradict or complicate anything. Sometimes all you need to do is emphasize and that will be just fine. You donâ€™t always have to have an underlining complicated for an emotion to make it more enhanced. Do be afraid to use the Thesaurus to also improve an emotion. Such things as â€œhappyâ€ is a nice emotional word
column20: but think of how much more powerful it is when you heard some is â€œoverjoyedâ€ or â€œcontent.â€ She how these emotions matched up with a body language can give two different styles of happiness? Mix and match to find what works best for your character at the time.  More In Depth Information  What Iâ€™ve stated above is more of a simplistic overview. IF you truly want to improve yourself
